Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps Teams: Wireless Sensor Network Based Localization and Navigation for Precision Agriculture
Award.AbstractNarration:
According to a USDA summary circa 2015, there exist 2.08 million farms in the US, spanning a total of 913 million acres with an average farm size of 438 acres. Efficiency and productivity are integral factors in profitability from agricultural operations. Efficiency and productivity critically depend on the level of automation or semi-automation, continuous real-time monitoring, continuous and timely intervention, and our ability to benefit from emerging scientific and technological innovations (e.g. low-cost and high-precision sensors, wireless technologies, etc). As part of previous NSF funded research, this I-Corps team has pioneered efficient localization algorithms for wireless sensor networks. The algorithms offer computational speed and real-time localization accuracy. Motivated by the broader impacts of these algorithms, the team is now interested in evaluating their commercial and technological potential to increase efficiency and productivity in American agriculture. This NSF I-Corps project and its potential outcomes are expected to be of high interest to the US Department of Agriculture. Potential customers include (1) Large agricultural companies; (2) Manufacturers of precision agriculture equipment; (3) Precision farming service providers; and most importantly (4) American farmers.

This NSF I-Corps project will enable the team to better understand the market needs for an "electronic localization system," identify competing precision farming solutions, and build a demonstrable prototype. The proposed hardware consists of an array of sensor nodes with calibration and measurement capabilities (e.g. moisture, nitric oxide, sodium, temperature, etc.) that can be deployed throughout a given farmland. Software consists of data fusion and data-2-decision algorithms developed via our previously funded NSF technology (i.e. localization of a node). Functionally, each node is capable of detecting anomalies (e.g. high temperature and low moisture) and sending alert signals to the base station. The system alerts the farmer (or an autonomous vehicle) and offers precise localization and navigation to the concerned site for executing real-time remedial measures. The technology aims to eliminate dependence on global positioning systems (GPS), thereby offering a cost-effective precision farming solution for many rural environments where GPS is either undependable or unavailable. In this proposed I-Corps project, the team will (1) Interact with potential clients; (2) Investigate market needs and market size; (3) Learn about the supply chain and distribution channels; and (4) Talk to potential venture investors about what kind of precision agriculture innovations would be attractive for investment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has begun with the attempts to find Customer segment related to academic research and concludes with a series of strategies to deal the challenges in the headway. We have investigated many magazines, journals (both business and technical) and finally chose Farmers as our customer line of segment that fits in well within the scope of our sensor technology research expertise. Our objective is to increase productivity by 10 percent with the help of real time monitoring the soil moisture and temperature through an array of wireless sensor networks. Also, identify the dry and arid location and alert the farmer for quicker deployment and better water management.

After a detailed market research analysis and 56 interviews with clients such as farm advisors, farmers, farm managers, agriculture service providers and equipment dealers, we have pivoted to goods warehousing with navigational track support as our new line of customer segment due to reliability, price sensitivity and lack of demand issues. In this segment we interviewed 100 potential customers such as warehouse managers, IT managers, and stockers. To the credit of NSF’s I-Corps guidance, we have honed our market research capabilities and came up with a preliminary market research analysis report to avoid any surprises show up out of blue on the product commercialization that occasional leads to rechecks. We further narrowed down the window of customer line of segment to target specific domain within the capacity of our product. The program benefited us with the knowledge on how engaging in a hypothesis-driven discovery of the customer and their anticipated needs. The program also assisted us in developing strategies that lead to scalable and sustained impact beyond the typically short life cycle of the initial development. 

Outcomes on Identification of Value Propositions

(a)   Innovative quick response oriented wireless sensor network.

(b)   Round-the-clock monitoring and ease in accessibility.

(c)    Advanced data fusion systems (algorithms).

(d)   Compatible and upgradeable.

(e)    Quick alert system.

Outcomes on Identification of Customer Segments

 (I)    Outcomes on Identification of Farmer Line of Segment

(a)   Commercial availability of many similar products in the market to the customers.

(b)    Unreliability of product in application.

(c)     Price sensitivity of product.

   (II) Outcomes on Identification of Goods Warehousing Line of Segment

(a)   Enhancing the productivity of employees by 10% with installation of mapping, location detection systems with indoor sensors for goods.

(b)   Though the product generated high interest among customers but the size of market is significantly low.

Outcomes on Identifying Challenges in Utilizing the Proposed Technology in Precision Agriculture

The primary pain of farmers (First customer line of segment) is multifaceted, for example California primary pain is “labor”, Michigan primary pain is “Weather”, Midwest grain industry primary pain is “Market price”. Therefore, the application of our product does not converge within the horizon of a primary pain. In addition, availability of similar commercial products in the market, unreliability, price sensitivity and lack of customer interest in product were some of the reasons that held us back from proceeding further.

Outcomes on Identifying Challenges in Utilizing the Proposed Technology in Goods Warehousing

There were many challenges pointed out in the goods warehousing line of segment when it comes to developing and utilizing navigation and mapping network. These issues were summarized as follows: 1) pin point mapping of selected goods in a warehouse, 2) data log maintenance, and 3) ease of accessibility in terms of software platform and simple upgradation. The objective is to increase the productivity of warehouse employees by 10% per day with installation of mapping as well as location detection systems with indoor sensors for goods.  our proposed study will reduce the amount of time an employee may take to locate an item resulting in a more efficient utilization of employees per hour work. The importance and relevance of each of these challenges were further developed as part of our project.  The outcomes of I-Corps program efforts have implications for broader community of users who benefit from navigation and mapping network with advanced data fusion systems in goods warehousing.
